get_number_of_commits()¶

To be done

Intended to extract new data regarding the number of commits for every author so that it could also be considered as a parameter when creating the ML model to assess the risk of a commit :return: None

Features.feature_extraction module¶

” @author : Richard Delwin Myloth

class Features.feature_extraction.Authors(data, column_name)¶

Bases: object

This class is concerned with extracting author names and mapping them to a numeric value

Done:

extract names map values from distinct string to integers

Additional:

  • extract number of commits for an author

map_author_to_val()¶

This function was intended to clean author names and map them to integer values which could have been an indication for author commit experience, author’s seniority etc. :return: Dictionary of authors

class Features.feature_extraction.Key(data)¶

Bases: object

To extract keywords from the commit messages # the keywords classified into five categories

# 1. corrective (“fix””bug”, “wrong”, “fail”, “problem”) # 2. addition, (“new”, “add”, “requirement”, “initial”, “create”) # 3. non functional (“doc”, “merge”) # 4. perfective (“clean”, “better”) # 5. preventive (“test”, “junit”, “coverage”, “assert”)

map_keywords_to_val(column_name)¶
Parameters

column_name – comment (type - String)

Returns

None

The commented parts: - + Lines are commented to just find the keywords and sort them rather than assigning values

class Features.feature_extraction.Size(data)¶

Bases: object

This class is used to remove non-numeric data, leaving behind only numeric data also accounts for removing whitespaces which might be present for merge commits

keep_numeric_data(column_name)¶
Parameters

column_name – could be (intended for) files changed, lines added, lines deleted but can also be used for any other column which is supposed to be having only numeric data (type - String)

Returns

None
